sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Neoral(R) (modified cyclosporine for microemulsion capsules or solution) is not bioequivalent to oral Sandimmune(R) (cyclosporine, USP capsules or solution) and cannot be used interchangeably
  • the total daily dose of modified cyclosporine for microemulsion capsules or solution should always be administered in 2 divided doses
  • conversion from Sandimmune(R) to Neoral(R): start Neoral(R) at same daily dose as previously used Sandimmune(R); adjust Neoral(R) dose to attain preconversion cyclosporine blood trough concentration with monitoring every 4 to 7 days after conversion and more frequently with doses greater than 10 mg/kg/day
  • Cardiac transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Cardiac transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant
  • Graft versus host disease; Prophylaxis: 4 to 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 2 divided doses; studies initiated therapy with 3 to 5 mg/kg/day continuous IV infusion beginning 1 to 2 days prior to transplantation which was converted to oral formulation as soon as was possible
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant
  • Plaque psoriasis (Severe), Recalcitrant, in nonimmunocompromised patients: initial, 2.5 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses twice daily for at least 4 weeks; dose may be increased 0.5 mg/kg/day at 2-week intervals; MAX 4 mg/kg/day
  • Renal transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Renal transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Severe), With inadequate response to methotrexate: initial, 2.5 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses twice daily; dose may be increased by 0.5 to 0.75 mg/kg/day after 8 weeks and again after 12 weeks; MAX 4 mg/kg/day
  • Ulcerative colitis (Severe): 8 to 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY; in studies, therapy was usually initiated with IV cyclosporine 2 to 4 mg/kg/day and converted to oral therapy as soon as possible

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and effectiveness not established for prophylaxis of organ rejection in patients younger than 1 year old and for treatment of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis in patients younger than 18 years old
  • Neoral(R) (modified cyclosporine for microemulsion capsules or solution) is not bioequivalent to oral Sandimmune(R) (cyclosporine, USP capsules or solution) and cannot be used interchangeably
  • the total daily dose of modified cyclosporine for microemulsion capsules or solution should always be administered in 2 divided doses
  • conversion from Sandimmune(R) to Neoral(R): start Neoral(R) at same daily dose as previously used Sandimmune(R); adjust Neoral(R) dose to attain preconversion cyclosporine blood trough concentration with monitoring every 4 to 7 days after conversion and more frequently with doses greater than 10 mg/kg/day
  • Cardiac transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: (1 year or older) initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Cardiac transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: (1 year or older) initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant
  • Renal transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: (1 year or older) initial, 15 mg/kg/day ORALLY given initially 4 to 12 hours before transplant or postoperatively as a single dose, then divided twice daily into 2 equal doses for 1 to 2 weeks; titrate subsequent doses to achieve predefined blood concentrations
  • Renal transplant rejection; Prophylaxis: adjunctive adrenal corticosteroid therapy is recommended early posttransplant

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic impairment (all indications): lower doses may be required to maintain blood concentrations in recommended range
  • (heart, kidney, or liver transplant) nephrotoxicity: reduce dose if nephrotoxicity develops during treatment
  • (psoriasis) renal impairment: use is contraindicated
  • (psoriasis) nephrotoxicity: decrease dose by 25% to 50% for any serum creatinine elevation from pretreatment level of 50% or more and for elevation of 25% or more on 2 tests 2 weeks apart; discontinue if reversibility of serum creatinine to within 25% of baseline is not attained after 2 dose reductions
  • (psoriasis) adverse events (eg, hypertension, clinically significant lab abnormality): decrease dose by 25% to 50% to control event; discontinue use if dose reduction does not control abnormality or if condition is severe
  • (rheumatoid arthritis) renal impairment: use is contraindicated
  • (rheumatoid arthritis) nephrotoxicity: decrease dose by 25% to 50% for serum creatinine elevation of 30% or more from pretreatment level; discontinue use if dose reduction does not control abnormality or if condition is severe
  • (rheumatoid arthritis) adverse events (eg, hypertension, clinically significant lab abnormality): decrease dose by 25% to 50% to control event; discontinue use if dose reduction does not control abnormality or if condition is severe

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cardiac transplant rejection; Prophylaxis
  • Liver transplant rejection; Prophylaxis
  • Plaque psoriasis (Severe), Recalcitrant, in nonimmunocompromised patients
  • Renal transplant rejection; Prophylaxis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Severe), With inadequate response to methotrexate
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Alopecia
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Graft versus host disease; Prophylaxis
  • Lung transplant rejection; Treatment and Prophylaxis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Ulcerative colitis (Severe)

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
• Oral (Capsule, Liquid Filled; Solution)
    CycloSPORINE, a systemic immunosuppressant, may increase the susceptibility to infection and development of neoplasia. Hypertension and nephrotoxicity can occur at recommended dosages, and the risk increases with increasing dose and duration of cycloSPORINE therapy. Monitor blood levels and renal function to avoid toxicity. Neoral(R) and Sandimmune(R) are not bioequivalent and cannot be used interchangeably without physician supervision. Psoriasis patients previously treated with PUVA and to a lesser extent, methotrexate or other immunosuppressive agents, UV-B, coal tar, or radiation therapy, are at an increased risk of developing skin malignancies when taking cycloSPORINE.
  • Oral (Capsule, Liquid Filled)
    Only physicians experienced in management of systemic immunosuppressive therapy for the indicated disease should prescribe cycloSPORINE, modified. Increased susceptibility to infection and the possible development of lymphoma may result from immunosuppression. Hypertension and nephrotoxicity can occur at recommended dosages, and the risk increases with increasing dose and duration of cycloSPORINE therapy. Monitor blood levels and renal function to avoid toxicity. CycloSPORINE, modified (Gengraf(R)) and cycloSPORINE (Sandimmune(R)) are not bioequivalent and cannot be used interchangeably without physician supervision. Psoriasis patients previously treated with PUVA and to a lesser extent, methotrexate or other immunosuppressive agents, UV-B, coal tar, or radiation therapy, are at an increased risk of developing skin malignancies when taking cycloSPORINE.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Concomitant use with PUVA or UVB, radiation therapy, coal tar, methotrexate, or other immunosuppressive agents in patients with psoriasis
  • Hypersensitivity to cycloSPORINE or to any ingredients in the formulation of the product
  • Comorbid abnormal renal function, malignancies, or uncontrolled hypertension in patients with rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- CycloSPORINE (Gengraf(R) or Neoral(R)) and cycloSPORINE (Sandimmune(R)) are not bioequivalent; close supervision and monitoring recommended as dosage adjustments may be required
  • -- Hypertension and nephrotoxicity may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- Increased risk for infection and neoplasms
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- Hypertension may occur at recommend dosages; increased risk with higher doses and longer treatment duration; dose reduction and antihypertensive therapy may be required
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Risk for malignancy development, particularly of the skin, is related to intensity and duration of immunosuppression
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Hyperkalemia, significant, sometimes associated with hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, has been reported
  • -- Hyperuricemia, significant, has been reported
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Syndrome of thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia may occur; increased risk of graft failure; dose adjustments or drug discontinuation may be required
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Hepatotoxicity and liver injury (ie, cholestasis, jaundice, hepatitis, liver failure), possibly fatal, have been reported; risk increases with high doses; dose reduction may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Risk for development of lymphoma and other malignancies is related to intensity and duration of immunosuppression
  • -- Serious and opportunistic infections (eg, bacterial, viral, fungal, protozoal infections, polyomavirus infection, activation of latent viral infections); increased risk associated with immunosuppression; BK-virus associated nephropathy may lead to renal allograft loss; monitoring and dose adjustment recommended
  • -- Polyoma virus infections, including fatal cases, have been reported; may include JC virus-associated progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) or polyoma virus-associated nephropathy resulting in deterioration of renal function or renal graft loss; monitoring recommended
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Encephalopathy (ie, impaired consciousness, convulsions, visual disturbance, loss of motor function, movement disorders, and psychiatric disturbances) has been reported; most cases reversible upon dose reduction or discontinuation
  • -- Seizures have occurred, particularly with concomitant high-dose methylprednisolone
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Optic disc edema, including papilloedema, with possible visual impairment secondary to intracranial hypertension has been reported in transplant patients
  • Renal:
  • -- BUN or serum creatinine increases may occur; increased risk with higher doses and longer treatment duration; monitoring recommended and dosage adjustments or discontinuation may be required
  • -- Chronic nephrotoxicity and renal dysfunction, including structural kidney damage, may occur despite dose reduction or discontinuation; monitoring recommended
  • Other:
  • -- Conditions in which alcohol use should be minimized or avoided (eg, pregnancy, breastfeeding, liver disease, epilepsy); formulations contain alcohol
  • -- Elderly patients; increased risk of decreased renal function; monitoring recommended; cautious dose selection and monitoring recommended, dosage adjustments may be required
  • -- Excessive sunlight or ultraviolet light exposure should be avoided; increased risk of malignancies
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Concomitant use of agents that decrease cycloSPORINE absorption (eg, orlistat) should be avoided
  • -- Concomitant use of aliskiren not recommended
  • -- Concomitant use of bosentan should be avoided
  • -- Concomitant use of dabigatran should be avoided
  • -- Concomitant use of grapefruit or grapefruit juice should be avoided
  • -- Vaccination may be less effective; avoid use of live attenuated vaccines during cycloSPORINE therapy
  • -- Concomitant use of potassium-sparing medications (diuretics, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor antagonists) or potassium-containing supplements should be avoided

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Cyclosporine: AAP: Cytotoxic drugs that may interfere with cellular metabolism of the nursing infant.
  • Cyclosporine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Hirsutism, Pruritus
  • Endocrine metabolic:Serum triglycerides raised (15%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (2.7% to 15%), Diarrhea (5% to 13%), Gingival enlargement (3.8%), Nausea (5.5% to 18%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (15.9 to 25%), Tremor (13%)
  • Renal:Serum creatinine raised (18% to 48%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension (19% to 50% or more)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperkalemia, Hypomagnesemia
  • Gastrointestinal:Pancreatitis (rare)
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity (4% to 7%)
  • Immunologic:Disease due to BK polyomavirus, Secondary malignant neoplastic disease
  • Neurologic:Encephalopathy, Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, Seizure
  • Ophthalmic:Optic disc edema
  • Renal:Capillary thrombosis, Glomerular, Nephrotoxicity (10% to 30%), Renal interstitial fibrosis
  • Other:Infectious disease

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: CycloSPORINE suppresses cell-mediated immune reactions through specific and reversible inhibition of immunocompetent lymphocytes in the G0- and G1-phase of the cell cycle. Among the preferentially inhibited T lymphocytes, the T-helper cell is the main target; although, the T-suppressor cell may also be inhibited. CycloSPORINE also inhibits production and release of lymphokines, including interleukin-2.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 1.5 to 2 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: incomplete (adults); 43% (pediatrics)
  • Effects of food: decreased systemic availability

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Intestinal wall: small amount, via CYP3A
  • Kidney: small amount, via CYP3A
  • Liver: extensive, via CYP3A
  • M1, M9, M4N metabolites (major): unknown activity
  • inhibitor of CYP3A4 and P-glycoprotein
  • substrate of CYP3A4 and P-glycoprotein

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: primary route of elimination
  • Renal excretion: 6%
  • Dialyzable: No (hemodialysis); No (plasmapheresis)
  • Total body clearance: adult, 5.9 to 10.2 mL/min/kg; pediatric 8.7 to 16.6 mL/min/kg

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • (oral solution) dilute with room temperature apple juice or orange juice; avoid switching diluents frequently
  • (oral solution) mix solution and apple or orange juice in a glass container and drink immediately; rinse glass container with more juice and consume
  • (capsules and oral solution) give consistently in regard to time of day and meals

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• prevention of organ rejection: cyclosporine blood concentrations routinely
  • prevention of organ rejection: conversion from Sandimmune(R) to Neoral(R); cyclosporine blood trough concentrations every 4 to 7 days and serum creatinine and blood pressure every 2 weeks during the first 2 months; in patients with poor Sandimmune(R) absorption, cyclosporine blood trough concentrations until stabilized, at least twice a week, or daily if the initial dose exceeds 10 mg/kg/day
  • prevention of kidney rejection: serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels; rapid rise in creatinine (greater than 0.3 mg/dL/day), creatinine greater than 25% above baseline, and a BUN/creatinine ratio less than 20 may indicate rejection
  • prevention of organ rejection: renal function; frequently; nephrotoxicity risk increases with increasing dose and duration, characterized as a gradual rise in creatinine (less than 0.15 mg/dL/day), a creatinine plateau less than 25% above baseline, and a BUN/creatinine ratio 20 or greater
  • prevention of organ rejection: hepatic function tests; regularly, especially when patients are receiving high doses of cyclosporine
  • prevention of organ rejection: serum lipids; during therapy
  • prevention of organ rejection: serum magnesium; during therapy
  • prevention of organ rejection: serum potassium; during therapy
  • prevention of organ rejection: signs or symptoms of opportunistic infection (eg, activation of latent viral infection including BK virus-associated neuropathy); early intervention is critical
  • prevention of organ rejection: signs or symptoms of malignancy; before and during therapy
  • psoriasis: clinical response may be seen within 2 weeks; stabilization may require 12 to 16 weeks of therapy
  • psoriasis: renal function; 2 creatinine levels at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy (or if serum creatinine measures 25% or greater above baseline), and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: hepatic function; regularly during therapy
  • psoriasis: CBC; at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: serum lipids; at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: serum magnesium; at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: serum potassium; at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: uric acid levels; at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • psoriasis: presence of skin changes; including occult infections prior to therapy initiation, and malignant or premalignant skin lesions or tumors, prior to and throughout treatment
  • psoriasis: signs or symptoms of opportunistic infection (eg, activation of latent viral infection including BK virus-associated neuropathy); early intervention is critical
  • psoriasis: blood pressure; at baseline (on at least 2 occasions), every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • rheumatoid arthritis: cyclosporine blood concentrations; periodically
  • rheumatoid arthritis: erythrocyte sedimentation rate may indicate efficacy
  • rheumatoid arthritis: therapeutic response generally seen within 4 to 8 weeks; should be seen within 16 weeks of therapy initiation; includes improvement in tender and swollen joint count
  • rheumatoid arthritis: renal function; 2 creatinine levels at baseline, every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • rheumatoid arthritis: hepatic function; regularly in all patients; monthly in patients receiving regimens including concomitant methotrexate
  • rheumatoid arthritis: CBC; monthly in patients receiving regimens including concomitant methotrexate.
  • rheumatoid arthritis: serum lipids; during therapy
  • rheumatoid arthritis: serum magnesium; during therapy
  • rheumatoid arthritis: serum potassium; during therapy
  • rheumatoid arthritis: blood pressure; at baseline (on at least 2 occasions), every 2 weeks for the first 3 months of therapy, and then monthly if stable
  • rheumatoid arthritis: signs or symptoms of opportunistic infection (eg, activation of latent viral infection including BK virus-associated neuropathy); early intervention is critical
  • rheumatoid arthritis: signs or symptoms of malignancy; before and during therapy

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    • Oral Capsule, Liquid Filled: 25 MG, 50 MG, 100 MG
    • Oral Solution: 100 MG/ML
  • Gengraf
    • Oral Capsule, Liquid Filled: 25 MG, 100 MG
    • Oral Solution: 100 MG/ML
  • Neoral
    • Oral Capsule, Liquid Filled: 25 MG, 100 MG
    • Oral Solution: 100 MG/ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CYCLOSPORINE
USES: CycloSPORINE is a cyclic polypeptide extracted from fungal species. It is primarily used as an immunosuppressant for organ transplant, but is also used to treat psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, other autoimmune disorders, and dry eyes. PHARMACOLOGY: The exact mechanism of action is unknown, but cycloSPORINE is thought to suppress helper T-lymphocyte proliferation, and activation. It is also thought to decrease lymphokine release. TOXICOLOGY: CycloSPORINE inhibits sodium-dependent uptake of bile salt transport across canalicular membranes resulting in cholestasis. It is also directly nephrotoxic. Because it is an immunosuppressant, it can also increase risk of infection, lymphoma, and lymphoproliferative disorders. EPIDEMIOLOGY: CycloSPORINE ingestion is an uncommon cause of poisoning. Ingestions are usually unintentional, and rarely result in severe manifestations. Parenteral overdose, though uncommon, are usually more serious than oral overdose. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Usually occurs via the oral route of administration, and may include headache, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, dysesthesias, taste abnormalities, flushing, tremor, fasciculations, and edema. SEVERE TOXICITY: Usually occurs via the parenteral route of administration, and may include hyperkalemia (severe), nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, encephalopathy, neurotoxicity, gastrointestinal bleed, metabolic acidosis, allergic reaction, acute lung injury, CNS depression, seizure, coma, dysrhythmias, and cardiac arrest. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Hypertension, elevated BUN/serum creatinine, hirsutism, infection, tremor, gingival hyperplasia, headache, hypertriglyceridemia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, leg cramps, paresthesias, dizziness, stomatitis, edema, rash, arthralgia, flushing, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, hemolytic anemia, depression, optic disc edema, intracranial hypertension, glomerular capillary thrombosis, pancreatitis, malignancy, diabetes, hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and hypomagnesemia have been reported with therapeutic use.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CYCLOSPORINE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Most exposures are mild and require only supportive care. Replete magnesium if needed. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Support respiratory and cardiovascular function as needed. Treat severe hyperkalemia, resulting in ECG changes, with dextrose/insulin and calcium. Treat seizures with benzodiazepines. Toxic nephropathy has been treated with low dose dopamine. PARENTERAL: Parenteral exposures are often more serious than oral ingestions. Treat in a similar manner to a large oral overdose. EYE EXPOSURE: CycloSPORINE also comes as an ophthalmic solution used to treat dry eyes and may increase the risk of an ocular infection. Flush the eye copiously with tepid tap water or saline with at least 1 liter per eye. Consider using local anesthetic drops for pain control and to ease irrigation.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Generally, no decontamination is needed in the prehospital setting. HOSPITAL: Activated charcoal may be utilized for worrisome ingestions.
  • Airway management: Provide supportive care.
  • Antidote: None
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor serum electrolytes, especially magnesium and potassium. Monitor renal function, liver enzymes, and CBC with differential. Measure triglycerides. Institute continuous cardiac monitoring and obtain an ECG. Consider obtaining acetaminophen or salicylate concentrations if there is any uncertainty regarding drug ingested.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Because of its large molecular weight, hemodialysis or other forms of enhanced elimination are of no benefit.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with unintentional ingestions may be observed at home if asymptomatic. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Symptomatic patients and those with deliberate ingestions should be evaluated in a healthcare facility. Patients who have minimal symptoms 6 hours after ingestion may be discharged. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Symptomatic patients requiring ongoing supportive care may need admission. Once asymptomatic for 6 hours, they may be discharged. CONSULT CRITERIA: Severe poisoning may occur with large oral or parenteral exposures of cycloSPORINE. If concerned, consult a medical toxicologist for guidance. Consult specialists if hepatotoxicity, renal toxicity, or neurologic symptoms persist.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CYCLOSPORINE
TOXICITY: ORAL: CycloSPORINE does not appear to be highly toxic orally. Doses of 30 to 400 mg/kg produced only minor symptoms. Adults ingesting 5 g acutely, or 25 g over 8 days, have not developed serious toxicity. Inadvertent ingestions of 500 and 600 mg by a 2-month-old and 3-year-old child (104 and 46 mg/kg, respectively) did not result in significant toxicity. PARENTERAL: An adult died of cerebral edema after receiving an intravenous infusion of 30 mg/hour (a ten-fold overdose) for 13 hours immediately after a lung transplant. Neonates receiving 179 to 400 mg/kg IV developed severe metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure, and cyanosis. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Dosing regimens vary widely. TRANSPLANT REJECTION: ADULT: ORAL: Initially, 15 mg/kg as a single dose 4 to 12 hours before cardiac, liver, or renal transplant; continue same dose as daily dose for 1 to 2 weeks and then decrease by 5% per week to a maintenance dose of 5 to 10 mg/kg/day; IV: Initially, 5 to 6 mg/kg/day as a single dose 4 to 12 hours before cardiac, liver, or renal transplant; continue same initial dose as daily dose until patient can tolerate oral formulation. PEDIATRIC: ORAL: Initially, 15 mg/kg administered 4 to 12 hours before cardiac, liver, or renal transplant or postoperatively; continue same dose as daily dose for 1 to 2 weeks; total daily dose should be divided into 2 equal daily doses; doses are then adjusted to attain center-defined trough blood concentrations. RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS (SEVERE): ADULT: Initially, 2.5 mg/kg/day orally divided twice daily; dose may be increased by 0.5 to 0.75 mg/kg/day at 8 weeks and 12 weeks; MAX: 4 mg/kg/day. PEDIATRIC: Safety and efficacy not established.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid vaccines during therapy unless approved by healthcare professional.
  • To decrease the risk of skin malignancies, advise patient to avoid excessive exposure to ultraviolet light.
  • Drug may cause hypertension, renal dysfunction, hirsutism, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, headache, tremor, or gingival enlargement.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of transplant rejection, infection, or encephalopathy (impaired consciousness, seizures, visual disturbances).
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of hepatotoxicity or nephrotoxicity, especially patients receiving high-dose therapy.
  • Warn patient that rinsing the oral solution syringe with water either before or after use will cause a variation in dose and should be avoided.
  • Patient should not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this drug.
  • Patient should avoid concomitant potassium-sparing drugs, potassium supplements, and food/salt substitutes that are high in potassium.
  • Tell patient that there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
